page.title: 07THE PRIORY OF OUR LADY
page.content: The Priory occupies 30 acres west of the A23 at Sayers Common (O.S.265188) There are 2 ponds, 1 natural and 1 man made, and a path dating from Druid times. The buildings, planned as a circle, incorporating some 600 year old farm buildings, were erected in 1978. They include "Kingslands" a Georgian house the deeds of which date from 1580, when Queen Elizabeth 1 made a rent of one red rose. There are nuns' quarters, kitchen, laundry, dining rooms, library, guest wing with bedrooms, 2 chapels and an exceptionally beautiful church, shaped like a conical oasthouse. The Canonesses of St. Augustine began in 14th. century Holland, and spread to Belgium, later English nuns escaped there from religious persecution in 1609. In 1886 a community returned and set up a Priory in Haywards Heath.
